questions.text: Which of the following epithelia does not line the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The middle ear is not lined by keratinizing squamous epithelium, and hence its presence anywhere within the middle ear cleft is considered cholesteatoma.

Various kinds of epithelia lining the middle ear are:

  • Ciliated columnar- around the eustachian tube opening (Protympanum)
  • Pavement like- attic/epitympanum
  • Cuboidal- rest

questions.text: Otoscopic image of a patient with a history of repeated middle ear infections is shown below. Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is also known as epidermosis

questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris in the left upper quadrant of the left tympanic membrane. This along with clinical scenario is suggestive of cholesteatoma which is also known as epidermosis or keratoma

Cholesteatoma is the presence of stratified squamous epithelium in middle ear where it is not usually present, i.e., skin in wrong place.

A central white mass, consisting of keratin debris is produced by the matrix. For this reason, it has also been named epidermosis or keratoma.

The term cholesteatoma is a misnomer because it neither contains cholesterol crystals nor it is a tumor to merit the suffix “oma.”

questions.text: You see a patient with a history of painless foul-smelling ear discharge and loss of hearing for the past year. He had undergone tympanoplasty on the same ear 3 years back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of secondary acquired cholesteatoma. The history of middle ear infection and hearing loss  after surgery of the tympanic membrane makes the diagnosis more likely.

Classification of cholesteatoma:

1. Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

2. Primary acquired cholesteatoma presents with no history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars flaccida. 

3. Secondary acquired cholesteatoma presents with a history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars tensa.

Note: This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy, earlier the question described a tertiary cholesteatoma, however, since the universally used classification for cholesteatoma in most standard books do not include tertiary cholesteatoma, it has been altered to describe a secondary cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: Which of the following theories does not explain the origin of cholesteatoma?

choices.text: Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
von Bekesy theory of  mucosal metaplasia

questions.solution:
von Békésy proposed the traveling wave theory, whereas Sade’s metaplasia theory explains the origin of cholesteatoma.

Cholesteatoma can be of 2 main types:

  • Congenital cholesteatoma - explained by the presence of congenital cell rests within the middle ear and other parts of the temporal bone.
  • Acquired cholesteatoma - explained by a pathology either within the mastoid air cell system and eustachian tube drainage, or the tympanic membrane epithelium.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

questions.text: What is the most common site for primary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution: Prussak’s space is the most common site of primary cholesteatoma. It is the space in the epitympanum lying in between pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was referred to an otolaryngologist for subjective left-sided hearing loss. A hearing test revealed mild conductive hearing loss at low and middle frequencies. Otoendoscopy showed a mass with the appearance as shown below. Which of the following criteria is used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the otoendoscopy showing a white pearly mass behind the intact eardrum in the anterosuperior quadrant is suggestive of congenital cholesteatoma. Levenson criteria should be satisfied in order to diagnose this condition.

Levenson criteria:

  1. A white mass behind the normal tympanic membrane
  2. Normal pars tensa and pars flaccida
  3. No prior history of otorrhoea
  4. No prior history of otological procedure
  5. Episodes of otitis media with effusion should not be considered as exclusion criteria.

Another popular guideline used is Derlaki and Clemis which includes all the above except for the 4th criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the expansion of cholesteatoma and destruction of bone?

choices.text: Release of enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase at the site of destruction
Destruction of bone mediated by pressure necrosis
Osteoclasts and mononuclear infiltrates play a role in bone destruction
Erosion of ossicles is more common in children compared to adults

questions.solution:
Cholesteatoma does not cause bone destruction by pressure necrosis.

Bone destruction by cholesteatoma has been attributed to enzymes liberated by osteoclasts and mononuclear inflammatory cells such as:

  • Collagenase
  • Acid phosphatase and
  • Proteolytic enzymes.

Pediatric cholesteatoma (PC) has more inflammation and greater chances of ossicular erosion compared to adults. However, PC has lesser chances of petrous labyrinth invasion and lateral semicircular canal fistula formation.

questions.text: A patient presented to your OPD for a second look surgery following a canal wall-up procedure for cholesteatoma removal. Where is the residual disease most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Residual cholesteatoma is most likely to be seen in the sinus tympani.

The involvement of sinus tympani, along with posterior mesotympanum, is a recognized risk factor for residual cholesteatoma. This is because it is particularly difficult to remove the disease from these areas. Canal wall-up procedures have a higher risk of leaving residual disease behind than the canal wall-down procedures.  

Sinus tympani or infra pyramidal recess is the medial of the two posterior spaces in the middle ear.

It is bounded by:

  • Pyramid and vertical segment of facial nerve laterally
  • The stapes & oval window medially
  • Ponticulus superiorly
  • Subiculum inferiorly

Image showing sinus tympani:

questions.text: Patients with tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media are considered safe compared to atticoantral disease. What is the reason?

choices.text: Does not progress into malignancy usually
Does not involve the mastoid air cells

questions.solution:
Tubotympanic type (TTD) of CSOM is considered the safe type in relativity to atticoantral disease (AAD) as TTD has less chance of complications than AAD.

Note: TTD can also lead to complications but the incidence is much less than that in AAD.

Related Pearl: Classification of CSOM

  Tubo-tympanic Attico-antral
Old name Safe type Unsafe ear
Recent name Mucosal variant Squamosal disease
Discharge

Profuse

Mucoid

Non-foul smelling

Non-blood stained

Scanty

Purulent

Foul-smelling

May be blood stained
Site Mostly in the pro-tympanum, i.e., part of middle ear around the Eustachian tube orifice Mostly involves the epi-tympanum/attic and involves the mastoid antrum via the aditus
Perforation Central (most common: Antero-inferior quadrant)

Attic (Pars flaccida) or

Marginal (most common: Postero-superior)
Granulations Uncommon Common
Polyp Pale, rare Fleshy red, common
Cholesteatoma Absent Present
Complications Rare Common
Treatment Medical/ surgical (Tympanoplasty) Always surgical (Mastoidectomy)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the given otoscopy finding in a child with poor scholastic performance?
questions.solution:
The given otoscopic image shows a subtotal perforation. It involves all four quadrants of the tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance. 

Related Pearl: Types of tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties. 

Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM:

  • As a sequela of acute otitis media
  • Ascending infection via the eustachian tube
  • Allergic conditions

Bone destruction is not present in this type.

Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.

Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.

Related Pearl: Classification of CSOM

  Tubo-tympanic Attico-antral
Old name Safe type Unsafe ear
Recent name Mucosal variant Squamosal disease

Non-foul smelling

Non-blood stained

Foul-smelling

May be blood stained
Site Mostly in the pro-tympanum, i.e., part of middle ear around the Eustachian tube orifice Mostly involves the epi-tympanum/attic and involves the mastoid antrum via the aditus
Perforation Central (most common: Antero-inferior quadrant)

Attic (Pars flaccida) or

Marginal (most common: Postero-superior)

Polyp Pale, rare Fleshy red, common
Cholesteatoma Absent Present
Complications Rare Common

questions.text: A known case of tubotympanic disease was taken up for surgery and on examining the middle ear, few chalky white deposits were found between the ossicles. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Candidal infection of the middle ear

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tympanosclerosis. It is a sequela of long-standing middle ear disease where there are hyaline deposits within the middle ear, which calcify leading to impaired mobility of ossicles.

The common sites are the tympanic membrane, promontory, ossicles, joints, tendons, and oval and round windows.

When hyalinization and calcification involve only the tympanic membrane, it is known as myringosclerosis.

questions.text: A first-year ENT postgraduate sees a child with permanent perforation of the tympanic membrane.  Which of the following is a feature of such perforation?

choices.text: It is seen in acute suppurative otitis media
It is caused by necrotizing otitis externa
It has squamous epithelium at its edges
Medical management can be tried initially

questions.solution:
A permanent perforation is lined by squamous epithelium at its edges, hindering spontaneous healing.

Features of a permanent perforation:

  • Seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
  • Is similar to an epithelial lined fistulous tract
  • Cannot be medically managed, thus mandating surgery

questions.text: A young adult presents with a 3-year history of intermittent ear discharge. He complains of poor hearing, which improves during discharge periods, but is worse when the ear is dry. Which of the following explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the round window-shielding effect that is seen in tubotympanic type of CSOM.

The round window-shielding effect is where the ear discharge shields the round window from sound waves. During the inactive phase (no discharge), the sound strikes both the oval window and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is worse when the ear is dry.

Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the patient has worse hearing.

The term "cholesteatoma" originates from the Greek words "chole" meaning "lipids" and "steatos" meaning "fat." The name reflects the microscopic appearance of the tumor, which may contain a mixture of desquamated skin cells, cholesterol crystals, and other debris that can resemble a pearly substance when examined under a microscope.

questions.text: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media is posted for surgery. Preoperatively, the surgeon wants to assess the status of the ossicles so that he can be prepared for ossicular construction if required. Which of the following tests is useful here?
questions.solution:
The patch test is useful in assessing the status of the ossicles preoperatively so that the surgeon can be prepared for ossicular reconstruction if required. It is done in tubotympanic type of CSOM.

A thin paper-like cigarette foil is soaked in vaseline and cut into the size of perforation and is used to close the perforation. Pure tone audiometry is done before and after the closure of perforation. Results are as follows:

  • Improved hearing – intact ossicular chain
  • Decreased hearing – ossicular fixity or discontinuity
  • No improvement – technical fault or improper hearing.

Another test done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM is Bonsin's test. When the eardrum is painted with 1 in 20% solution of silver nitrate, the perforation stands out as a black spot against a white background.

Option A: Nine-step test is used to predict the ears at risk of middle ear barotrauma. 

Options B and D: The side-step test and Unterberger test are vestibular tests and are positive in perilymphatic fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media?

choices.text: Central perforation in antero-inferior quadrant is commonly seen
Blood stained ear discharge is seen
The discharge is scanty, purulent and foul smelling

questions.solution:
Central perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane is commonly seen in tubotympanic type, while marginal perforation in the postero-superior quadrant is commonly seen in atticoantral type of CSOM.

Bloody, scant, foul-smelling ear discharge, ear pain, hearing loss, and tinnitus are often seen in the atticoantral type of CSOM.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media?

choices.text: Involvement of Shrapnell's membrane is seen

questions.solution:
Atticoantral type also called unsafe or dangerous type involves perforation of Shrapnell's membrane or pars flaccida (attic perforation). 

The disease is often associated with a bone-eroding process such as cholesteatoma, granulations, or osteitis. The risk of complications is high in this variety.
